docs.lead_paragraph: In a decisive setback to the Giuliani administration's efforts to privatize New York City's public hospitals, the state's highest court ruled yesterday that city officials had overstepped their authority in trying to lease Coney Island Hospital to a private company. The State Court of Appeals ruled unanimously that the 1969 state law that created the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation to run the vast municipal hospital system did not permit the public corporation to sell off hospitals and other assets, or even to lease them to private entities. The hospital corporation runs 11 acute-care hospitals, 5 long-term care centers, a network of clinics and a health maintenance organization.

headline.main: Court Deals Blow to Giuliani's Hospital Privatization Plan

docs.abstract: New York State Court of Appeals, in decisive setback to Giuliani administration's efforts to privatize New York City's public hospitals, rules that city officials had overstepped their authority in trying to lease Coney Island Hospital to private company; holds that 1969 state law that created city's Health and Hospitals Corp to run vast municipal hospital system did not permit public corporation to sell off hospitals and other assets, or even to lease them to private entities (M)
docs.snippet: In a decisive setback to the Giuliani administration's efforts to privatize New York City's public hospitals, the state's highest court ruled yesterday that city officials had overstepped their authority in trying to lease Coney Island Hospital to a...

docs.lead_paragraph: After years of maintaining that its statistics on the labor productivity growth rate were generally reliable, the Government agency that produces the numbers now says they may be somewhat understated. In research to be published on Wednesday, the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics says that the current economic prosperity, and rising profits ''do not seem fully consistent with slow productivity growth.'' The new studies focused on four industries -- banking, insurance, construction and health services -- that seem robust but have registered no improvement in official productivity statistics in recent years.

headline.main: U.S. Data May Understate Productivity Gains

docs.abstract: Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics says statistics on labor productivity growth rate may be somewhat understated; holds current economic prosperity, and rising profits 'do not seem fully consistent with slow productivity growth; new studies focused on banking, insurance, construction and health services, industries that seem robust but have registered no improvement in official productivity in recent years; Edwin R Dean, chief of bureau's productivity division and author of one of three articles to appear in Labor Department's Monthly Labor Review, comments (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Relieving some of the political pressure for reform, the Government released new actuarial studies today extending the date at which Medicare can be expected to run out of money by seven years and Social Security insolvency by two years. The improved financial position of the Medicare and Social Security trust funds is largely the result of the strong economy over the last year, the trustees of the funds said in their annual report.

headline.main: Longer Solvency for Medicare and Social Security

docs.abstract: Government releases new actuarial studies extending date at which Medicare can be expected to run out of money by seven years, to 2015, and Social Security insolvency by two years, to 2034; improved financial position of Medicare and Social Security trust funds is largely result of strong economy over last year, trustees of funds say in their annual report; Pres Clinton says that despite good news, legislation strengthening programs should still be enacted this year; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: There's always an uneasiness when the doctor wants to talk about sex, a young woman said at a recent meeting of her lesbian support group. ''You know, when they ask, 'Are you having intercourse?' And you say, 'No,' '' said the woman, with amber skin and a short Afro. ''Then they ask, 'So you are not sexually active?' And you say, 'I didn't say that.' Then they ask, 'Well what do you do?' And you have to decide whether to lie or whether to come out.''

headline.main: New Clinics Let Lesbian Patients Be Themselves; An Effort to Help a Group That Often Shuns Doctors

docs.abstract: Article discusses growing concern in lesbian community over health care; notes that many lesbians, after admitting to their doctors that they are gay, have experienced feelings of uncomfortableness in discussing their sexual orientation; many lesbians have dropped out of health care system, putting them at greater risk for preventable illnesses and making them more likely to die from diseases that are treatable if detected early; growing movement is under way, led by lesbian health care providers and political advocates, has resulted in increase in number of health care centers that cater to lesbians; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: No one knows for sure how many there are. A police officer who is trying to track and close them before any more babies die says it is almost impossible to say. ''It's like counting the speakeasies in Chicago in the 1920's,'' the officer said. ''They don't advertise in the Yellow Pages.''
docs.abstract: Southern California's huge and often uninsured immigrant population is turning to underground health care system, unlicensed pharmacies and clinics that operate from back rooms of stores and homes, as sources of prescription drugs, often risking their health; task forces are trying to find them to shut them down, especially following deaths of two toddlers in Orange County, who died after receiving back-room injections; photos (M)
